title: 111_s159
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park Act". In this Act, key terms defined include City (Paterson, New Jersey), Commission (Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park Advisory Commission), Historic District (Great Falls Historic District), Management Plan (plan for the Park), Map (Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park boundary map), Park (Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park), and Secretary (Secretary of the Interior). The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" refers to the State of New Jersey. SEC. 3. PATERSON GREAT FALLS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. Establishment of the "Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park" in the State is subject to conditions set by the Secretary regarding land acquisition or donation agreements with the State or City. The Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park is established to preserve and interpret historical, cultural, and natural resources associated with the Historic District. The Secretary has agreements with the State, City, or other public entities to ensure that land within the Historic District is managed in accordance with the Act and that future land uses are compatible with the Park's designation. The Park includes various sites such as raceways, parks, hydroelectric plants, and historic ruins. The Paterson Museum and The Great Falls Visitor Center are part of the Park, with a Map available for public inspection. The Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register within 60 days of meeting certain conditions, including an official boundary map for the Park. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary administers the Park in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Organic Act and the Act of August 21, 1935. State and local jurisdiction within the Park boundaries is not affected, and cooperative agreements may be entered into as needed. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with the owner of the Great Falls Visitor Center or other significant properties within the Park to identify, interpret, restore, and provide technical assistance for preservation. The agreements grant the Secretary access to public areas for conducting tours and interpreting the properties. No changes or alterations are allowed without permission. Any changes or alterations to properties covered by a cooperative agreement require agreement from both the Secretary and the other party. Payments made by the Secretary are subject to an agreement that any conversion, use, or disposal of a project against the Act's purposes may require reimbursement to the United States. The Secretary may acquire land within the Park boundary by donation, with matching funds required for Federal funds received under a cooperative agreement. Non-Federal funds can be in the form of donated property, goods, or services. The Secretary may acquire land within the Park boundary by donation, purchase, or exchange. State-owned land can only be acquired by donation. Technical assistance and public interpretation of historic and cultural resources within the Historic District may be provided by the Secretary. The management plan for the Park includes acquiring land through donation, purchase, or exchange, with state-owned land only available through donation. Technical assistance and public interpretation of historic and cultural resources within the Historic District may be provided by the Secretary. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, must complete a management plan for the Park within 3 fiscal years. The plan should outline cost-sharing provisions for necessary improvements and maintenance, to be submitted to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, must complete a management plan for the Park within 3 fiscal years, outlining cost-sharing provisions for improvements and maintenance, to be submitted to the Senate's Committee on Energy and Natural Resources and the House's Committee on Natural Resources. SEC. 6. PATERSON GREAT FALLS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK ADVISORY COMMISSION. Established as the "Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park Advisory Commission" to advise the Secretary on the management plan. Composed of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with recommendations from the Governor, City Council of Paterson, and Board of Chosen Freeholders of Passaic County, New Jersey. The Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park Advisory Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with recommendations from the Governor, City Council of Paterson, and Board of Chosen Freeholders of Passaic County, New Jersey. Two members must have experience with national parks and historic preservation. The initial appointments must be made within 30 days of receiving all recommendations or 30 days after the Park is established. Members serve a 3-year term and can be reappointed for one additional term. The Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park Advisory Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with recommendations from the Governor, City Council of Paterson, and Board of Chosen Freeholders of Passaic County, New Jersey. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission meets at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members. A majority of the Commission constitutes a quorum. The Commission selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members, with terms not exceeding 1 year each. Compensation of members is addressed in Commission personnel matters. The Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park Advisory Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with recommendations from the Governor, City Council of Paterson, and Board of Chosen Freeholders of Passaic County, New Jersey. Members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Secretary provides staff and technical assistance as needed. The Commission, established to carry out its duties, may accept personnel from the State, political subdivisions, or entities represented on the Commission. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission, which will terminate 10 years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. STUDY OF HINCHLIFFE STADIUM.

The Secretary must complete a study on preserving and interpreting Hinchliffe Stadium within 3 fiscal years of funds availability. The study includes assessing the potential for National Historic Landmark status and options for maintaining its historic integrity.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriate funds are authorized for carrying out this Act.
